header.title: Das Zehnte Elf und Zwölfte Buch Moses
header.category: Grimoire, Western Esotericism, Solomonic Magic, Folk Magic, Divination

central_thesis: The book presents a comprehensive system for practical magic, including spirit conjuration (both benevolent and infernal), protective rituals, and divination methods, primarily aimed at achieving material wealth, protection, and knowledge of the future. It operates by leveraging divine and infernal powers through specific words, prayers, and symbols, purporting to reveal the "greatest and most important secret of all secrets."

structure_content.summary: This section outlines prayers and conjurations directed at the spirit Araton, using divine names and specific sigils, with the primary goal of manifesting material wealth in the form of gold pieces. It includes explicit instructions for the spirit's dismissal after the objective is achieved.

This part provides detailed, practical instructions for evoking a specific spirit, which is described as appearing in beggar's clothing. The purpose of this evocation is to acquire substantial financial gains, ranging from 10 florins up to one million in negotiable currency. The ritual is to be performed under a cloudy sky near a field tree, employing distinct 'barbarous names' for the evocation.

This section focuses on protective magic, presenting rituals and prayers designed as a 'Spiritual Shield against Spirits and bodily dangers.' It integrates traditional Christian elements such as prayers, verses from the Gospel of St. John, and references to a letter from Pope Leo, promising safeguarding from various hazards including spirits, plague, and general misfortunes.

This is the core grimoire segment, detailing an aggressive system for evoking and compelling various spirits (e.g., Aciel, Uniguel, Marbuel, Aciahel, Machiel, Baruel) for diverse objectives such as treasure discovery, gaining knowledge, and securing luck. It provides explicit instructions for constructing and consecrating magic circles, precise timing for evocations, and lengthy conjurations utilizing potent divine names and Christian authority. A key aspect is the explicit use of damnatio (damnation/cursing) against disobedient 'hellish spirits' to coerce them into delivering large sums of gold and silver. Comprehensive dismissal rites are also included.

structure_content.chapter_title: Entdeckte höhere Kenntniß des Geheimnisses, aus der Karte sich zukünftige Dinge vorzusagen.
structure_content.summary: Authored by Anton Brini, this section serves as a comprehensive guide to cartomancy (card reading) for predicting future events and determining 'lucky numbers' for lotteries. It frames itself as a scientific method, possibly influenced by Eteilla's system, offering intricate rules for card layouts, interpretations based on position and numerical values, and methods for numerical analysis relevant to gambling.

Presented by Ignaz Lorenz, this section details a powerful prayer and associated ritual dedicated to Saint Christopher. The ritual aims to compel spirits to bring money and involves specific preparatory steps such as making a consecrated crucifix and candles, constructing and consecrating three magic circles, and reciting a series of prayers and conjurations directed at St. Christopher to achieve financial gains within a specified timeframe.

key_concepts.definition: A specific set of conjurations, possibly referring to a wealth-attracting spirit or method, presented in two distinct sections with similar aims (wealth manifestation) but varying ritual instructions.

A direct and aggressive form of spirit evocation and binding, primarily utilizing Christian authority and divine names to compel infernal or 'hellish spirits' for material gain, knowledge, and other objectives.
The act of invoking and compelling entities, which can include angels, benevolent spirits, or 'hellish spirits,' through the use of prayers, divine names, sigils, and specific ritual actions.
The ritual cursing, binding, and threatening of spirits, often with explicit references to divine punishment and torment, employed to ensure their obedience and compliance with the magician's will.
A consecrated ritual space, typically drawn on the ground, serving both as a protective boundary for the practitioner during spirit evocations and as a containment field for the conjured entity.
Potent words and names of God (e.g., Agla, Adonai, Tetragrammaton, Jehovah Zehaoth) used within conjurations to invoke authority and compel spirits into obedience.
Esoteric or seemingly nonsensical words or phrases (e.g., Roratae veni, Zorocle veni) believed to possess inherent magical power when recited during evocations and conjurations.

A divination method involving the use of cards (tarot or similar) to predict future events, analyze current situations, and even calculate lottery numbers, presented within the text as a 'science' rather than mere fortune-telling.

A specialized prayer and ritual system invoking Saint Christopher, specifically designed to facilitate wealth manifestation through the action of compelled spirits, often involving Christian liturgical elements.
A core objective across multiple sections of the book, explicitly aimed at obtaining large sums of gold and silver through direct intervention and service of conjured spirits.

practical_system.description: The book outlines a multi-faceted magical system centered on spirit conjuration, divine intervention, and divination. It provides explicit instructions for evoking a range of spirits (benevolent, wealth-bringing, and 'hellish') to achieve specific objectives, primarily wealth, protection, and foresight. The system heavily relies on Christian elements (prayers, divine names, Christ's authority, saint invocation) alongside classical grimoire techniques like magic circles and symbolic characters. The 'Manual-Höllenzwang' (Infernal Compulsion Manual) is particularly operative in its detailed and aggressive methods for compelling spirits.
tools: Sigils/Characters: Specific symbols used in conjurations and protective magic.
Magic Circle: A consecrated boundary for protection and spirit containment, often drawn on the ground.
Parchment/Paper: For writing conjurations, sigils, and other ritual texts.
Candles: Consecrated candles (e.g., in Christoph-Gebet ritual).
Crucifix/Image of St. Christoph: Used in the Christoph-Gebet ritual.
Cards: Tarot or similar divination cards for Cartomancy.
Field Tree/Natural Setting: Specific locations for certain Habermann evocations.
Holy Water: Mentioned for its protective qualities and associated indulgences.
Divine Names/Barbarous Names: Oral or written invocations as part of conjurations.
rituals: Spirit Evocation for Wealth (Habermann): Involves specific prayers (e.g., to Araton), sigils, and direct demands for gold/silver. Performed in specific natural settings (e.g., under a cloudy sky, near a field tree).

Faustian General Compulsion: Requires drawing and consecrating magic circles using Trinity invocation, strict timing (days/hours), and long, detailed conjurations involving divine names and threats of damnatio against 'hellish spirits' to compel them to bring wealth or knowledge. Includes specific dismissal rites.
Protective Rituals (Colomanu-Buch): Utilizes Christian prayers, Gospel verses (St. John), and 'spiritual shields' for defense against spirits and bodily harm.

Christoph-Gebet for Money: A specialized ritual involving a consecrated crucifix, candles, a specific prayer to St. Christoph, and the construction of three magic circles to compel spirits for financial gain within a set timeframe.
Cartomancy and Lottery Prediction: Involves specific card layouts, interpretations based on card order and numerical values, and a method (Eteilla's system) for calculating 'lucky numbers.'

relevant_quotes.text: Das größte und wichtigste Geheimniss aller Geheimnisse!
So du das verborgene Geld erhalten hast, so brauche es zu Gottes Ehren, vergiß dabei der Armen nicht, dann wirst du Glück und Segen haben.

Dies wird bei bedecktem Himmel unter einem Felderbaum nach Belieben gemacht. So bald der Geist kommt, der in Bettlers Kleidung und Gestalt erscheint, rede ihn an und fordere nicht weniger als 10 fl., auch nicht mehr als eine Million in gangbarer Münze.
Ich N. N. zwinge euch, (höllische) Geister sicher dar zu erscheinen, durch das angenehmste Abendmahl des heiligen Leibes und Blutes unseres Herrn Jesu Christi,
Wir binden, verdammen und verfluchen euch (ihr Höllengeister)
Es werde gezwungen Gott durch seine Allmacht... durch sein eigen Wort... durch seine Christus-Kraft... durch Maria... durch seine Weisheit... durch seine Heiligkeit... durch seine Wahrheit.

critical_analysis.relevance: This work is highly relevant to the study of grimoire traditions, particularly those blending Christian theology with explicit demonology and wealth manifestation magic. It shows the evolution of Solomonic-style magic into a distinct 'Faustian' tradition within a Christianized occult framework. Its inclusion of cartomancy and lottery prediction also broadens its scope beyond typical grimoires, indicating a pragmatic approach to acquiring both spiritual and material advantage. It highlights the persistent human desire for power, protection, and prosperity through supernatural means, and the creative ways esoteric systems adapt religious dogma for magical ends. The publisher's foreword acknowledging the historical context of fear and the search for 'explanations' further contextualizes its societal role within esoteric history.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience is practitioners of Western Esotericism and Occultism, especially those interested in grimoire magic, Solomonic traditions, Christian-themed magic, and historical magical practices for wealth manifestation and protection. It is also of significant interest to academic researchers in religious studies, history, and folklore specializing in magic, as it provides a detailed example of a 'black book' from the early modern period, albeit in a later revised edition. The instructional nature of the text clearly indicates its intention for direct magical application by adept practitioners.
